primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in the cycle of human sin and injustice by taking the penalty upon Himself in Christ to establish a new moral order of righteousness.

subject.identificatie: God (specifically the Father and Son acting in unity)
tekstueel_bewijs: God made him to be sin
God arranged for his own self to pay the price

object.identificatie: Satisfaction of justice / The righteousness of God
tekstueel_bewijs: so that in him we might become the righteousness of God
justice is actually done; it is not a 'legal fiction'
must as an event of the moral order

ontvanger.identificatie: The 'Whole World' / The Hearers / The Oppressed

helper.identificatie: The Son (Jesus) as the sinless sacrifice
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus... stood forward to take the weight of sin upon himself
the self-offering of the Suffering Servant

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, and the Cycle of Retaliation
tekstueel_bewijs: the old world of Sin and Death
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is treated as a weight and a 'world' that requires a divine intervention from 'outside the structures' to break.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer bears witness to the completed work of Christ through endurance and non-violent struggle.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer / The Church (e.g., Dr. King, Romero)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program is a 'downpayment' or 'witness' to the already completed primary program.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God made him to be sin
God has not declared a general amnesty
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we need to weigh the Cross

voorbeelden: we do not like to believe that we deserve condemnation
we learn what it was that happened to Jesus
I have power to lay it down
that we may be enabled to bear witness

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The 'Devoir' (Must) is not a moralistic demand on the hearer, but a theological necessity placed upon God by His own nature.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (Condemnation deserved) through a rejection of ~S2 (Amnesty) to S1 (Righteousness) via the substitution of Christ.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ absorbs S2 so that the Receiver can move from ~S1 to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; the sermon explicitly rejects 'general amnesty' as unsatisfying to justice.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. God is the primary actor who pays the price that humans cannot pay. The human role is strictly receptive and subsequently witness-bearing.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: mentioning Dr. King and Romero as models

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God arranged for his own self to pay the price... instead of us.
The old world of Sin and Death came to an end on the Cross.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical and historical figures are used not as models of self-effort, but as evidence of God's 'downpayment' working through them.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Theocentric: God's power is seen in the endurance of the martyrs.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; the burden of 'paying' is removed.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Substitutionary atonement is the engine of the narrative.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the cosmic work of Christ to the ethical witness of the church is handled via the 'downpayment' metaphor.
spanning_punten: The tension between the 'already' of the Cross and the 'how long' of current injustice.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: the motif of substitution, as Jesus bows his head under the weight of the world's sin

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon mentions 'grace' enabling witness, but the Spirit is not explicitly named as the actant.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is a debt that 'must' be paid.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative structure is robustly theocentric. God is the Subject of all redemptive verbs.

identificatie_herstel.strategie: Maintain the current focus on the hearer as the beneficiary of the 'payment'.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Explicitly link the 'enabling' of witness to the Holy Spirit's power (Pouvoir-faire).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in maintaining God as the Subject of the Gospel while addressing real-world injustice.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric might focus on the emotional appeal of the 'Somebody has got to pay' anecdote, semiotics reveals that this anecdote functions as the 'Sender' (the demand for justice) that God Himself satisfies.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains 2 Cor 5:21; semiotics shows how the 'exchange' in the verse is the actual engine of the sermon's movement.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas helps identify that the 'Opponent' is not just personal sin, but a 'cycle' or 'world' that only a Subject from 'outside' can defeat.

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully avoids the 'angry Father' trap by emphasizing the unified will of the Trinity.
